chunks.content:
Transportation Manual

Introduction

Purpose: Transportation ensures that all drivers complete deliveries accurately, safely, and on time, while also serving as the liaison between drivers, customers, and internal departments.

Scope: Covers all transportation employees, supervisors, and their workflows, including school routes, street routes, backhauls, hotshots, equipment tracking, and reporting.

Team Structure

Mike Palma – Transportation Manager: Oversees department operations.

Delareese Delgado – Supervisor of Schools: Ensures school routes are completed by 2 PM.

Patrick Brown – Supervises alphabetical route IDs.

Victor Polanco – Supervises letter IDs and Connecticut routes, truck maintenance, fuel, cameras, cleaning, and safety compliance.

Chun Ng – Handles backhauls and unplanned “hotshots.”

Bernie – Handles backend operations, equipment tracking, and reporting.

Daily Workflow – Transportation Staff

Start of Shift (Approx. 2 AM)

Organize invoices, loading sheets, and route documents received from night clerks.

Assign drivers to routes and verify route IDs, keydrop documents, and e-jack batteries.

Track each driver’s equipment and ensure readiness for the shift.

Driver Monitoring

Track driver location and stops using IntelliShift.

Log remaining stops at 10 AM, 12 PM, 2 PM, 4 PM to monitor on-time completion.

Ensure school deliveries meet deadlines (latest by 2 PM).

Coordinate with nearby drivers to redistribute stops if someone is falling behind.

Issue Handling

Vehicle breakdowns: Contact Allegiance or Penske trucks; use in-house mechanics if possible.

Report truck issues in Telnet: 30, 18, date, route ID, E, 100, message, driver, location, follow, 1 (send), enter.

Customer issues: Merge calls with sales teams, resolve delivery errors, verify keydrops, and coordinate backhauls.

Safety issues: Monitor Netradyne cameras for speeding, hard braking, drowsiness, or distracted driving; enforce corrective action or bonus adjustments.

Driver Types and Responsibilities

A. School Drivers

Start times: Typically 5 AM.
synthetic_questions: Who is the supervisor for school routes?
What do we do at the start of the shift around 2 AM?
How do I report a truck breakdown in Telnet with the 30, 18 code?
What if a driver is falling behind—how do we handle redistributing stops?
I'm totally lost on who handles backhauls and hotshots—who is it?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Core transportation operations including safety, workflows, team structure, and specific procedures; highly actionable with clear steps but chunk cuts off abruptly.

jargon.keydrop documents: Documents associated with keydrop deliveries (leaving keys in a secure drop location)
jargon.IntelliShift: Software system for tracking driver locations and stops
jargon.Netradyne: Camera system for monitoring driver safety (speeding, hard braking, drowsiness, distracted driving)
jargon.route IDs: Unique identifiers for delivery routes (e.g., alphabetical or letter-based)
jargon.street routes: Regular urban or non-school delivery routes
jargon.e-jack batteries: Electronic device batteries required for routes
jargon.Telnet: Internal reporting system for logging truck issues

shift_start_time.context: Approximate start of shift for organizing documents and assigning drivers

school_route_deadline.context: School routes and deliveries must be completed by this time

stop_logging_times.context: Times to log remaining stops for monitoring on-time completion

school_driver_start_time.context: Typical start time for school drivers

chunks.content:
Obtain documents, batteries (if applicable), and review loading sheets

Deliver products to schools, ensuring accuracy due to potential fines ($500 per case).

Key duties:

Follow loading sheets carefully.

Handle refrigerated and dry items efficiently.

Maintain professional interactions with school staff.

Track deliveries, mark invoices, and return all equipment.

B. Street Drivers / NYC Drivers

Start times: Manhattan – 3 AM, other zones – 5 AM.

Collect paperwork and equipment from dispatch.

Deliver to restaurants, stores, or keydrop locations.

Verify product against invoices, check cases for mispicks, and handle refrigerated/dry items with helper.

For keydrop stops: Photograph storage for verification, lock premises afterward.

Follow DOT rules, traffic regulations, and maintain safety awareness.

C. Tractor Trailer Drivers

Require CDL A license.

Deliver products to warehouses or other Driscoll Foods locations.

May perform transfers and backhauls.

Same verification processes as street drivers.

Ensure full trucks leaving and returning to optimize efficiency and revenue.

Backhauls and Hotshots (Chun Ng)

Pre-planned backhauls: Ensure trucks return with product for revenue optimization.

Hotshots: Unplanned deliveries to collect product quickly.

Track and coordinate with drivers for timely execution.

Equipment Management (Bernie / Victor)

Monitor all trucks, jacks, e-jack batteries, straps, blankets, and handtrucks.

Maintain and repair equipment, assign to responsible employees, and document in reports.

Daily reporting ensures all resources are accounted for, available, and ready.

Reporting and Documentation

IntelliShift: Track truck location, driver, stops, and completion.

Netradyne: Monitor driving behavior and enforce safety standards.

Telnet: Log vehicle issues, route problems, and communicate with internal teams.

Dispatch sheets: Document driver assignments, route completion, and keydrop statuses.

End-of-day: Cease routes in IntelliShift, ensure all reports are accurate for the next day.

Safety and Compliance
synthetic_questions: What time do Manhattan Street Drivers start their shifts?
What do I do if I notice a mispick while checking cases against the invoice on a street route?
For keydrop stops, what's the exact procedure with photos and locking up?
My e-jack battery is dead halfway through the route - who do I report this to right now?
How do Tractor Trailer Drivers optimize efficiency with full trucks on backhauls and hotshots?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Core transportation procedures with compliance (fines, DOT), safety, and specific driver duties; actionable steps provided, mostly self-contained but references external systems/tools.

jargon.loading sheets: Documents detailing items to load for specific routes
jargon.keydrop stops: Unattended delivery locations accessed with a key, requiring photo verification of storage and locking afterward
jargon.mispicks: Incorrectly selected or picked items during loading or delivery
jargon.backhauls: Return trips loaded with product to generate revenue
jargon.Hotshots: Unplanned, urgent deliveries to quickly collect product
jargon.IntelliShift: telematics system for tracking truck locations, drivers, stops, and route completion
jargon.Netradyne: Camera-based system for monitoring driving behavior and enforcing safety
jargon.Telnet: System for logging vehicle issues, route problems, and communicating with internal teams
jargon.dispatch sheets: Documents assigning drivers to routes and tracking completion statuses

fine_per_case.context: Potential fine for inaccurate product deliveries to schools

chunks.content:
DOT rules: Hours of service, break requirements, vehicle inspections.

Road safety: Defensive driving, safe handling of refrigerated and dry products.

Incident management: Immediate reporting of accidents, vehicle issues, or customer complaints.

Equipment safety: Proper use of jacks, handtrucks, e-jacks, and securing loads.

Communication Protocols

Transportation acts as the central liaison between drivers, dispatch, sales, and warehouse.

All issues, delays, or customer concerns are communicated promptly.

Team members support each other and can cover for absences.

Overview

Transportation is essential to Driscoll Foods’ operations: ensures timely deliveries, driver safety, vehicle maintenance, equipment management, and customer satisfaction.

Effective teamwork, communication, and vigilance ensure operational efficiency, compliance with DOT, and maximized company revenue.
synthetic_questions: What are the DOT rules for hours of service and breaks?
What do I do if there's a vehicle issue during delivery?
How do I properly secure loads using e-jacks and handtrucks?
Why do I have to report every customer complaint right away—it's killing my schedule!
If I'm maxed out on HOS and delayed, who do I notify in dispatch or sales?
chunks.quality_reasoning: High importance due to compliance (DOT), safety, and core operations; broad overview applicable to entire transportation team; simple language requiring minimal expertise; self-contained as summary but lacks deep details; guides actions like reporting and communication but not step-by-step.

jargon.Hours of service: Federal regulations limiting daily/weekly driving and on-duty time for commercial drivers
jargon.break requirements: Mandatory rest periods mandated by DOT regulations
jargon.vehicle inspections: Required pre-trip and post-trip checks to ensure roadworthiness
jargon.Defensive driving: Proactive driving techniques to anticipate and avoid hazards
jargon.refrigerated products: Temperature-controlled cargo, often in reefer trailers
jargon.dry products: Non-perishable freight transported in dry van trailers
jargon.handtrucks: Manual two-wheeled carts for moving palletized loads
jargon.e-jacks: Electric-powered pallet jacks for lifting and moving heavy loads
jargon.securing loads: Using straps, chains, or tarps to fasten cargo and prevent shifting
jargon.dispatch: Operations center coordinating driver routes, loads, and schedules
